content.raw:
Maybe we can avoid the license question by changing some logic to not need the filesystem features. If I understand correctly boost::filesystem was used in this file to look for the directories with schema versions. I think it could be eliminated by having CMake create a header will a list of schema versions. 

Wasn't there also a comment somewhere about including the schema files inside of the libsdformat binary?
content.html:
Maybe we can avoid the license question by changing some logic to not need the filesystem features. If I understand correctly boost::filesystem was used in this file to look for the directories with schema versions. I think it could be eliminated by having CMake create a header will a list of schema versions.

Wasn't there also a comment somewhere about including the schema files inside of the libsdformat binary?

content.raw: I had earlier suggested exactly that, which was more-or-less embedding the SDF files in the library itself without grubbing around in the filesystem for it.  While I still think that has value, we will still need a replacement for boost::filesystem anyway.  For instance, in the code that reads in the URI for the model, we necessarily have to go grubbing around in the filesystem.  Thus, I think embedding the SDF files into the library is actually orthogonal to this.
content.html: I had earlier suggested exactly that, which was more-or-less embedding the SDF files in the library itself without grubbing around in the filesystem for it. While I still think that has value, we will still need a replacement for boost::filesystem anyway. For instance, in the code that reads in the URI for the model, we necessarily have to go grubbing around in the filesystem. Thus, I think embedding the SDF files into the library is actually orthogonal to this.

content.raw: Maybe the code for `exists` could be replaced with a call to `std::ofstream::open` followed by checking if the stream has the failbit set?
content.html: Maybe the code for exists could be replaced with a call to std::ofstream::open followed by checking if the stream has the failbit set?

content.raw: It's possible, but I'm doubtful it will work the same way.  In particular, exists() currently works for both files and directories; if std::ofstream::open is mapped down to the open() libc call, it won't work for directories properly I believe.  That being said, I can test it out and see what happens.
content.html: It's possible, but I'm doubtful it will work the same way. In particular, exists() currently works for both files and directories; if std::ofstream::open is mapped down to the open() libc call, it won't work for directories properly I believe. That being said, I can test it out and see what happens.

content.raw:
Ha, my intuition was completely wrong!  But this still won't work.

On Linux, your suggestion of using std::ofstream works just fine for both files and directories.  However, on Windows, std::ofstream::open works OK for files, but not for directories.

It is actually doesn't change things appreciably here, since we still need all of the infrastructure to support is_directory().  Still, it was an interesting thing to try :).
content.html:
Ha, my intuition was completely wrong! But this still won't work.

On Linux, your suggestion of using std::ofstream works just fine for both files and directories. However, on Windows, std::ofstream::open works OK for files, but not for directories.

It is actually doesn't change things appreciably here, since we still need all of the infrastructure to support is_directory(). Still, it was an interesting thing to try :).

content.raw: Yeah, that was kind of my thinking, but I wasn't sure if that was allowed here.  If we do go that way, I'll amend the license and add a comment saying where I pulled the code from.
content.html: Yeah, that was kind of my thinking, but I wasn't sure if that was allowed here. If we do go that way, I'll amend the license and add a comment saying where I pulled the code from.

content.raw:

The copyright notices in the Software and this entire statement, including
the above license grant, this restriction and the following disclaimer,
must be included in all copies of the Software, in whole or in part, and
all derivative works of the Software, unless such copies or derivative
works are solely in the form of machine-executable object code generated by
a source language processor.
~~~

seems like we need a copy of the boost license in the relevant new files

content.raw: I switched the license, but what I did was to copy what the license header looked like in boost's operation.cpp (where I got most of this code from).  It doesn't have the whole license, but a URL to it, so I'm guessing that is good enough.  Let me know if you think otherwise, and I can put the whole text in (it is not all that long anyway).

It doesn't have the whole license, but a URL to it, so I'm guessing that is good enough. Let me know if you think otherwise, and I can put the whole text in (it is not all that long anyway).

content.raw: Thanks, I'll cc @\_jrivero_  to see if he thinks debian would be satisfied with this license treatment
content.html: Thanks, I'll cc @_jrivero_ to see if he thinks debian would be satisfied with this license treatment

content.raw: @_jrivero_ Any thoughts on the license treatment here?  I'm ready to merge this once we think that the license is all set.
content.html: @jrivero Any thoughts on the license treatment here? I'm ready to merge this once we think that the license is all set.

content.raw:
Two things:

* I agree with Steve and reading the license we probably need to include a copy it somewhere in the code (it could be done by adding an independent license file or extending the headers to include it). I understand that what the boost headers does is supported by the fact of having a license file present in software.

* Debian has [its own system](https://www.debian.org/doc/packaging-manuals/copyright-format/1.0/#license-specification) to represent the different set of licenses used in a copyright metadata file which could include the full license text if needed. So it does not matter what we do here since the debian metadata can workaround with any of the implementations.
content.html:
Two things:

  • I agree with Steve and reading the license we probably need to include a copy it somewhere in the code (it could be done by adding an independent license file or extending the headers to include it). I understand that what the boost headers does is supported by the fact of having a license file present in software.

  • Debian has its own system to represent the different set of licenses used in a copyright metadata file which could include the full license text if needed. So it does not matter what we do here since the debian metadata can workaround with any of the implementations.

content.raw:
Thanks for the update, @_jrivero_ .  I've now updated the top of Filesystem.cc to include the full text of the Boost license.

Given that this was a comment-only change, I'm going to go ahead and assume the previous approvals still stand.  Thus, I'm going to merge this up.  Thanks everyone for the reviews!
content.html:
Thanks for the update, @jrivero . I've now updated the top of Filesystem.cc to include the full text of the Boost license.

Given that this was a comment-only change, I'm going to go ahead and assume the previous approvals still stand. Thus, I'm going to merge this up. Thanks everyone for the reviews!

content.raw:
Has anyone checked if this proposed API matches the c++17 API?

* http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/filesystem

I don't know if the new standard is different from boost.
content.html:
Has anyone checked if this proposed API matches the c++17 API?

  • http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/filesystem

I don't know if the new standard is different from boost.

content.raw:
Good point.  A quick comparison:

* current_path() - Same, except that std:: version returns a "path" object instead of a std::string
* create_directory() - Same, except that std:: version takes a "path" object instead of a std::string
* exists() - Same, except that std:: version takes a "path" object instead of a std::string
* is_directory() - Same, except that std:: version takes a "path" object instead of a std::string
* append() - Not in std::filesystem.  That's mostly because I created that out of whole cloth, since I don't really like the use of the overloaded operator / for this (which is what both boost and std::filesystem do).

With the minor exception of append, it seems like it will be pretty trivial to convert from this code to C++17 std::filesystem, when the time comes.  However, since we have to support older compilers for a while, I'm going to assume this code will live for a few years.
content.html:
Good point. A quick comparison:

  • current_path() - Same, except that std:: version returns a "path" object instead of a std::string
  • create_directory() - Same, except that std:: version takes a "path" object instead of a std::string
  • exists() - Same, except that std:: version takes a "path" object instead of a std::string
  • is_directory() - Same, except that std:: version takes a "path" object instead of a std::string
  • append() - Not in std::filesystem. That's mostly because I created that out of whole cloth, since I don't really like the use of the overloaded operator / for this (which is what both boost and std::filesystem do).

With the minor exception of append, it seems like it will be pretty trivial to convert from this code to C++17 std::filesystem, when the time comes. However, since we have to support older compilers for a while, I'm going to assume this code will live for a few years.

content.raw: Yes.  Unfortunately, this doesn't completely get rid of boost, nor does it even completely get rid of boost::filesystem.  The last piece of boost::filesystem we use is the directory iterator, which was *very* complicated to port from Boost.  I haven't yet decided on what to do with that, but I figured I would make some progress here anyway.
content.html: Yes. Unfortunately, this doesn't completely get rid of boost, nor does it even completely get rid of boost::filesystem. The last piece of boost::filesystem we use is the directory iterator, which was very complicated to port from Boost. I haven't yet decided on what to do with that, but I figured I would make some progress here anyway.

content.raw: Ahh, good to know then. Thanks for the clarification. I was too excited about removing filesystem :)
content.html: Ahh, good to know then. Thanks for the clarification. I was too excited about removing filesystem :)

content.raw: You are absolutely right, Carlos. I removed that code and made it use std::to_string now.  Thanks!

I removed that code and made it use std::to_string now. Thanks!

content.raw: Oh, sorry about that :(.  Let me do a quick test and see if that fixes it.
content.html: Oh, sorry about that :(. Let me do a quick test and see if that fixes it.

content.raw:
So, unfortunately, on Windows (where codecvt is used), that doesn't work.  I get errors about how codecvt_utf8 is not a member of std.  So it looks like we do need codecvt.

That being said, this is only really needed for Windows.  So what I'll do instead is move the include inside the Windows-specific header section, which should solve this for now.
content.html:
So, unfortunately, on Windows (where codecvt is used), that doesn't work. I get errors about how codecvt_utf8 is not a member of std. So it looks like we do need codecvt.

That being said, this is only really needed for Windows. So what I'll do instead is move the include inside the Windows-specific header section, which should solve this for now.

content.raw: On a related note, should Trusty be part of the CI any build?  I have more changes coming, and I don't want to be continually breaking it.
content.html: On a related note, should Trusty be part of the CI any build? I have more changes coming, and I don't want to be continually breaking it.

content.raw:
Trusty (and other platforms) are part of our CI system, they just are not selected to be "the reference platforms" for the PR CI cycle but they run daily to catch this kind of problems. Don't worry about breaking Trusty or other of the CI platforms, we can fix them as soon as the build cop detect the problem. This kind of errors (which depend of the Linux distribution) are not really common.

Thanks for the quick fix.
content.html:
Trusty (and other platforms) are part of our CI system, they just are not selected to be "the reference platforms" for the PR CI cycle but they run daily to catch this kind of problems. Don't worry about breaking Trusty or other of the CI platforms, we can fix them as soon as the build cop detect the problem. This kind of errors (which depend of the Linux distribution) are not really common.

Thanks for the quick fix.
